Package org.jtrim2.stream

Class FluentSeqProducer<T>

java.lang.Object
org.jtrim2.stream.FluentSeqProducer<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of the elements to be produced
public final class FluentSeqProducer<T> extends Object
Defines a convenient fluent style builder for producers producing a single sequence of elements. Instances of this class can be created through the toFluent() method of SeqProducer.

Mutator like methods always return a new instance and do not change the original SeqProducer instance.

For simple factory methods for initial producer implementations, see the factory methods in SeqProducer.

Thread safety

Instances of this class are immutable, and are therefor safe to be used by multiple threads concurrently. This property does not extend to the wrapped SeqProducer.

Synchronization transparency

Methods of this class are synchronization transparent, so they can be called in any context (e.g.: while holding a lock).
See Also:
  • SeqProducer.toFluent()
  • FluentSeqGroupProducer

  • Method Details

    • apply

      public <T1> FluentSeqProducer<T1> apply(Function<? super SeqProducer<T>,? extends SeqProducer<T1>> configurer)
      Transforms the wrapped SeqProducer using the given function and returns a fluent style builder for the transformation result. This method exists to allow fluent style continuation using custom transformations. For example: 
      
 builder
     .apply(SeqProducer::flatteningProducer)
     // ...

      For an instance of FluentSeqProducer named builder, this method call is equivalent to configurer.apply(builder.unwrap()).toFluent().

      Type Parameters:
      T1 - the type of the elements produced by the returned producer
      Parameters:
      configurer - the transformation transforming the wrapped producer. This argument cannot be null, and the transformation cannot return null.
      Returns:
      the wrapped SeqProducer transformed using the given function as fluent style builder. This method never returns null.
      See Also:
      • SeqProducer.flatteningProducer

    • concat

      public FluentSeqProducer<T> concat(SeqProducer<? extends T> nextProducer)
      Returns a producer producing the elements this producer, then producing the elements of the producer given in the arguments in this order. For example, if this producer produces [1, 2, 3, 4], and the producer in the arguments producers [5, 6], then the returned producer will produce [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6].
      Parameters:
      nextProducer - the producer producing the second part of the sequence. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the elements of this producer and the given producer in this order. This method never returns null.

    • map

      public <R> FluentSeqProducer<R> map(SeqMapper<? super T,? extends R> mapper)
      Returns a producer producing the elements produced by this producer after transformed by the given mapper. Note that the mapper is not necessarily a one-to-one mapper, it might even filter or add more elements.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the elements produced by the returned producer
      Parameters:
      mapper - the mapper mapping the elements of this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the elements produced by this producer after transformed by the given mapper. This method never returns null.

    • mapContextFree

      public <R> FluentSeqProducer<R> mapContextFree(ElementMapper<? super T,? extends R> mapper)
      Returns a producer producing the elements produced by this producer after transformed by the given mapper. Note that the mapper is not necessarily a one-to-one mapper, it might even filter or add more elements.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the elements produced by the returned producer
      Parameters:
      mapper - the mapper mapping the elements of this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the elements produced by this producer after transformed by the given mapper. This method never returns null.

    • batch

      public FluentSeqProducer<List<T>> batch(int batchSize)
      Returns a producer producing the same elements as this producer but grouped into lists of size batchSize (except for the final list, which may contain less). Note that as a side-effect, the processing steps will receive elements only after batchSize number of elements are received or when the stream processing ends.

      For example, if this producer is producing [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8], and batchSize == 0, then the returned producer will produce [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6], [7, 8]].

      Parameters:
      batchSize - the number of elements to be collected into each (except the last one) produced list. This argument must be greater than or equal to 1.
      Returns:
      a producer grouping elements into lists of size batchSize (except the last list). This method never returns null.
      See Also:
      • SeqProducer.flatteningProducer
      • FluentSeqGroupProducer.batch

    • peek

      public FluentSeqProducer<T> peek(SeqConsumer<? super T> seqPeeker)
      Returns a producer producing the same elements as this producer, but doing the given processing action before providing the element for the next processing step.
      Parameters:
      seqPeeker - the consumer doing the defined action on the produced sequence. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the same elements as this producer, but doing the given processing action before providing the element for the next processing step. This method never returns null.

    • peekContextFree

      public FluentSeqProducer<T> peekContextFree(ElementConsumer<? super T> peeker)
      Returns a producer producing the same elements as this producer, but doing the given processing action before providing the element for the next processing step.
      Parameters:
      peeker - the consumer doing the defined action on the produced sequence. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the same elements as this producer, but doing the given processing action before providing the element for the next processing step. This method never returns null.

    • limit

      public FluentSeqProducer<T> limit(long maxNumberOfElements)
      Returns a producer producing the first maxNumberOfElements elements of this producer. If this producer produces less than or equal to maxNumberOfElements elements, then this method will do effectively nothing.

      Note: This feature relies on the fact that the exceptions are rethrown to the caller as is.

      Parameters:
      maxNumberOfElements - the maximum number of elements the returned producer supposed to produce. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the first maxNumberOfElements elements of this producer. This method never returns null.

    • toBackground

      public FluentSeqProducer<T> toBackground(String executorName, int queueSize)
      Returns a producer moving the consumer to a background thread. The implementation puts the produced elements into a blocking queue, and proceeds to get further elements. This allows the producer and consumer to run in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.
      Parameters:
      executorName - the name given to the executor running the consumer task. This name will appear in the name of the executing thread. This argument cannot be null.
      queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the consumer thread is processing. That is, the consumer thread is effectively act as part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are queueSize + 1. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
      Returns:
      a producer moving the consumer to a background thread. This method never returns null.

    • toBackground

      public FluentSeqProducer<T> toBackground(TaskExecutor executor, int queueSize)
      Returns a producer moving the consumer to a background thread. The implementation puts the produced elements into a blocking queue, and proceeds to get further elements. This allows the producer and consumer to run in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.

      Note that it is normally expected that the executor can run at least a single task (which will run for the whole duration of the whole processing uninterrupted), when submitted from the context where the jobs would be running otherwise. If that is not the case, then the implementation might assume that the job submitted to the executor will eventually start for the purpose of queue settings. However, dead-lock will only arise in case not even a single task submitted to the given executor can start running, and in that case dead-lock is a necessity.

      Parameters:
      executor - the executor running the consumer task. This argument cannot be null.
      queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the consumer thread is processing. That is, the consumer thread effectively acts as part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are queueSize + 1. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
      Returns:
      a producer moving the consumer to a background thread. This method never returns null

    • toForEachable

      public ForEachable<T> toForEachable()
      Returns a ForEachable providing the elements of this producer. Notice that ForEachable accepts a Consumer which does not declare any checked exceptions, while this API usually allows producers and consumers to throw any instance of Exception. Therefore, the returned ForEachable have to (and will) rethrow checked exceptions wrapped into a RuntimeException.

      Note: Unlike most part of this stream API, the returned ForEachable considers InterruptedException thrown by this producer. That is, when this producer throws an InterruptedException, the current thread is reinterrupted, and the exception is rethrown wrapped into a RuntimeException.

      Returns:
      a ForEachable providing the elements of this producer. This method never returns null.

    • withConsumer

      public CancelableTask withConsumer(SeqConsumer<? super T> seqConsumer)
      Returns an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer.
      Parameters:
      seqConsumer - the consumer processing the elements produced by this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer. This method never returns null.

    • withContextFreeConsumer

      public CancelableTask withContextFreeConsumer(ElementConsumer<? super T> consumer)
      Returns an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer. The same consumer is applied to each elements independently.
      Parameters:
      consumer - the consumer processing the elements produced by this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer. This method never returns null.

    • withCollector

      public <R> CancelableFunction<R> withCollector(Collector<? super T,?,? extends R> collector)
      Returns an action which, when executed, processes the elements of the sequence produced by this producer the same way as the Stream.collect does.

      For example, the following code produces the list [2, 4, 6, 8]: 

      
 List<Integer> result = SeqProducer.copiedArrayProducer(1, 2, 3, 4)
     .toFluent()
     .mapContextFree(ElementMapper.oneToOneMapper(e -> 2 * e))
     .withCollector(Collectors.toList())
     .execute(Cancellation.UNCANCELABLE_TOKEN);
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of result of the collection or reduction operation
      Parameters:
      collector - the collector collecting or reducing the elements of this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an action which, when executed, collects and returns the elements of this producer using the given Collector. This method never returns null.
      See Also:
      • collect(CancellationToken, Collector)

    • collect

      public <R> R collect(CancellationToken cancelToken, Collector<? super T,?,? extends R> collector) throws Exception
      Processes the elements of the sequence produced by this producer the same way as the Stream.collect does.

      For example, the following code produces the list [2, 4, 6, 8]: 

      
 List<Integer> result = SeqProducer.copiedArrayProducer(1, 2, 3, 4)
     .toFluent()
     .mapContextFree(ElementMapper.oneToOneMapper(e -> 2 * e))
     .collect(Cancellation.UNCANCELABLE_TOKEN, Collectors.toList());
      This method is effectively the same as calling: withCollector(collector).execute(cancelToken).
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of result of the collection or reduction operation
      Parameters:
      cancelToken - the cancellation token which should be checked if the processing is to be canceled before completing the whole processing. There is no guarantee that the implementation will detect the cancellation request, but a best effort check will be made. If cancellation was detected by this call, then it must respond by throwing an OperationCanceledException. This argument cannot be null.
      collector - the collector collecting or reducing the elements of this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the result of the collection or reduction. Normally a collector should not return null, so in that case this method will not return null.
      Throws:
      OperationCanceledException - thrown if cancellation of the stream processing was detected by this method call
      Exception - thrown if there was a processing failure
      See Also:
      • withCollector(Collector)

    • toSingleGroupProducer

      public FluentSeqGroupProducer<T> toSingleGroupProducer()
      Returns a FluentSeqGroupProducer producing the same sequence of elements as this producer as a single sequence. This method is a bridge between the SeqGroupProducer and SeqProducer.
      Returns:
      a FluentSeqGroupProducer producing the same sequence of elements as this producer as a single sequence. This method never returns null.

    • unwrap

      public SeqProducer<T> unwrap()
      Returns the underlying SeqProducer instance.
      Returns:
      the underlying SeqProducer instance. This method never returns null.
